Sure the difference don't be as dramatic as it is now, but even so, because a difference is presence complains will be inevitable.

We do not live in a perfect world, so it is literally impossible for everyone to have "the best ping", so Riot decided on this compromise.
40 ms worse compared to 100 ms worse... seems like a pretty damn good compromise to me

For us, the solution isn't alleviating East Coast woes by tossing them over the rockies onto the West Coast.

If we had decided to move the servers to Newfoundland or another coastal location on the East Coast, yes, it would absolutely be a "tables are turned" flip, and we wouldn't be solving anything! Instead, we focused on a centralized location that offered the best balance between coasts to the east and west, as well as a midpoint between Canadian and US traffic. 

The end goal is not one coast being stronger than the other. The goal is to cover a HUGE geographic region by a common ping threshold of below 80ms. We feel like we can get there for almost everyone regardless of which coast you're on.  It'll take some work and we'll need some input from everyone, but we feel confident we can get there.
What are east coast players being retroactively given  for being at a disadvantage for all these years,

It will not. Networking goes a lot deeper than just the physical location of the server, and Riot is making sure that they are covering as many as these variables as possible.

They are not just moving the server, but making several other improvements as well.

If they duplicated or mirrored servers it would split the player base into two. That's bad. If you are trying to create some kind of peer to peer between more than 1 server on the east and 1 on the west you are creating delay and a lot of traffic and hops anyways. (Would be a nightmare). I think WoW servers cap out at like 50,000 players and look how many of those there were. LoL had some 16 million on one server. With this they looked at the location and centralized according to population per capita and I assume players geographic locations (an average of the 2) and then created 'highways' to those locations via dedicated ISP to relay the signal. So basically it will be better. People on the west coast are worried about 20-40's of a few more Milli-seconds but how many games have you played with a dropped or lagged player that ruined a game? I also am on the west coast but this sounds good. The "Model" for hosting in the West coast harkens back to silicon valley days, now a days the internet is everywhere. It is an antiquated stigma.
